title: Sleep Better — 2 Week Program
shortDescription: A practical 2-week (14-day) program with brief lessons and exercises to improve sleep habits using evidence-based strategies (sleep hygiene, stimulus control, relaxation, and simple CBT-I techniques).
description: This 14-day program teaches short, practical strategies to improve sleep: consistent scheduling, healthy sleep practices, brief relaxation exercises, worry-management at night, and planning for sustainable changes. Each lesson takes about 5–15 minutes and links to in-app tools for journaling or practice.
notes: Blocks of type 'action' map to in-app routes (for example: /thought, /abcd, /relax). 'exercise' blocks include durationMinutes. Use prompts to capture sleep observations in Thought Record or ABCD.

lessons.title: Intro — Sleep basics
lessons.summary: Understand why consistent sleep matters and take a baseline sleep note.

blocks.title: Why sleep matters
blocks.content: Good sleep supports mood, focus, immune function and learning. Small changes in routine often lead to better sleep within days to weeks.

blocks.title: Baseline sleep note
blocks.content: Write down your usual bedtime, wake time, and how many hours you typically sleep on workdays and free days.

blocks.title: Journal
blocks.content: Record one change you'd like to try this week (eg: earlier wind-down). Save it to Thought Record if you'd like.

lessons.title: Set a consistent schedule
lessons.summary: Pick a realistic target bedtime and wake time you can keep every day.

blocks.title: Consistency helps
blocks.content: Keeping a stable sleep window strengthens your body clock and makes falling asleep easier.

blocks.title: Choose your sleep window
blocks.content: Decide on a target wake time and bedtime that give you ~7–9 hours. Write them down and plan to stick to them for the next week.

blocks.title: Plan
blocks.content: Note one realistic change to support the schedule (eg: move alarm 15 minutes earlier).

lessons.title: Create a wind-down routine
lessons.summary: Design a 20–30 minute pre-sleep ritual to signal your body it's time to sleep.

blocks.title: Wind-down elements
blocks.content: A wind-down may include dim lights, low-stimulation activities (reading, light stretching), and avoiding screens. Aim for the same routine nightly.

blocks.title: Design the routine
blocks.content: Write a simple 20–30 minute sequence you'll use before bed for the next week.

blocks.title: Try it tonight
blocks.content: After trying, note what you did and whether it felt relaxing.

lessons.title: Stimulus control basics
lessons.summary: Use your bed only for sleep and intimacy — get up if you can't sleep.

blocks.title: Stimulus control rule
blocks.content: If you can't fall asleep within ~20 minutes, get out of bed, do a quiet activity in low light, and return only when sleepy. This helps the bed regain its sleep cue.

blocks.title: Plan a 'get up' strategy
blocks.content: Identify a calm place/activity you'll use if you can't sleep (eg: sit and read in dim light).

blocks.title: Reflect
blocks.content: Note how long it usually takes you to fall asleep and whether you'll try the 20-minute rule tonight.

lessons.title: Relaxation skills
lessons.summary: Practice a short relaxation exercise to reduce physical tension before bed.

blocks.title: Progressive relaxation (5 min)
blocks.content: Tense then relax each major muscle group, moving from feet to head or vice versa. Breathe slowly while doing it.

blocks.title: After practice
blocks.content: Write whether tension decreased and how easy it was to do.

lessons.title: Caffeine, alcohol & naps
lessons.summary: Small timing changes to caffeine, alcohol and napping can help sleep quality.

blocks.title: Timing matters
blocks.content: Caffeine can affect sleep for 6+ hours. Alcohol may help you fall asleep but fragments sleep later. Long naps can reduce sleep pressure at night.

blocks.title: Check your intake
blocks.content: Note today when you consume caffeine/alcohol and whether you nap. Aim to avoid caffeine after early afternoon and keep naps short (20–30 min) or remove them if they impact night sleep.

blocks.title: Plan change
blocks.content: Choose one timing to adjust (eg: no coffee after 2pm) and record it.

lessons.title: Week 1 — Review & refine
lessons.summary: Review what helped and refine your plan for week 2 (focus on stimulus control and schedule).

blocks.title: Review week 1
blocks.content: You experimented with schedule, wind-downs, stimulus control and relaxation. Small consistent steps are key.

blocks.title: Refine
blocks.content: Pick one habit to keep and one to adjust next week.

blocks.title: Keep tools handy
blocks.content: Use the Relax tool or Thought Record when night-worry starts.

lessons.title: Managing night-time worry
lessons.summary: Brief strategies to handle worries that arrive in bed.

blocks.title: Night worry is common
blocks.content: The quiet of night can amplify worries. Use brief strategies to postpone or contain worry so it doesn't block sleep.

blocks.title: Worry postponement
blocks.content: If a worry arrives, note it on paper with a single sentence and a time to revisit (eg: tomorrow 6pm). Then return to your wind-down.

blocks.title: Try it
blocks.content: Record one worry you postponed and whether it reduced night thinking.

lessons.title: Sleep restriction (intro)
lessons.summary: Learn the idea of matching time in bed to actual sleep to increase sleep drive (brief explanation only).

blocks.title: What is sleep restriction?
blocks.content: Sleep restriction temporarily reduces time in bed to increase sleep pressure, then gradually increases it. It's effective but best done with careful tracking.

blocks.title: Track tonight
blocks.content: Note your actual sleep time tonight (estimate) to inform whether a small restriction might help later.

blocks.title: Journal
blocks.content: If curious about sleep restriction, note questions and consider trying small changes before committing to a strict schedule.

lessons.title: Optimize the bedroom
lessons.summary: Small environmental tweaks often improve sleep (light, noise, temperature).

blocks.title: Environment tips
blocks.content: Keep your bedroom cool, dark and quiet. Remove or dim strong lights, use earplugs or white noise if needed, and reserve the room for sleep.

blocks.title: Quick check
blocks.content: Spend 5 minutes adjusting lights, curtains, and thermostat or noise to make the bedroom more sleep-friendly.

blocks.title: Note change
blocks.content: Record what you changed and whether falling asleep felt different.

lessons.title: Screens, blue light and evening habits
lessons.summary: Reduce stimulating screen use before bed and prefer low-light activities.

blocks.title: Why screens affect sleep
blocks.content: Bright screens and stimulating content raise alertness and suppress melatonin. A 30–60 minute reduction before bed helps most people.

blocks.title: Evening tech plan
blocks.content: Choose a cut-off time for screens (e.g., 30–60 min before bed) and a low-stimulation substitute (reading, calm music).

blocks.title: Try it
blocks.content: Note whether reducing screens changed how quickly you felt sleepy.

lessons.title: Boost sleep pressure safely
lessons.summary: Use daytime activity and light to support night sleep without racing the body.

blocks.title: Daytime behaviours
blocks.content: Daylight exposure, regular activity and avoiding long naps increase sleepiness at night. Aim for daytime movement and morning light where possible.

blocks.title: Daily activity plan
blocks.content: Add a 20–30 minute walk or light exercise earlier in the day and avoid naps longer than 30 minutes.

blocks.title: Record
blocks.content: Note the activity and whether you felt sleepier in the evening.

lessons.title: Bedtime worry strategies
lessons.summary: A few cognitive strategies to reduce perseverative thinking before sleep.

blocks.title: Cognitive strategies
blocks.content: Use brief containment (postponement), defusion (name the thought), and problem-solve only during a scheduled time to limit night-time rumination.

blocks.title: Containment practice
blocks.content: If worry arises, write it down quickly and tell yourself you'll review it at a scheduled 'worry time'. Then return to your wind-down.

blocks.title: Try and note
blocks.content: Record whether containment reduced repeated thinking.

lessons.title: Conclusion & maintenance
lessons.summary: Review changes, celebrate progress and set a simple maintenance plan to keep better sleep habits going.

blocks.title: Keep it simple
blocks.content: Sustainable sleep improvements come from consistent small changes: stable schedule, wind-down, reduced evening stimulation, and brief relaxation when needed.

blocks.title: Your maintenance plan
blocks.content: Write a short two-week plan: one nightly wind-down habit and one daytime habit (eg: morning light or daily walk). Save it.

blocks.title: Use the tools
blocks.content: When night-worry or sleeplessness recurs, use Relax, Thought Record or ABCD to track and respond.
